logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> PAY(HOURS_0_TO_8=ST, HOURS_8_TO_10=OT, AFTER(10)=DT)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the thresholds for straight time, overtime, and double time on a standard work schedule, which is the core function of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: 5x8 Schedule, Weekend & Holiday Overtime
rule_text:
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | TimeandOneHalf (1.5x)   | DoubleTime (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|-------------------------|-------------------|
| Saturday      |                 |                         | All hours         |
| Sunday        |                 |                         | All hours         |
| Stat Holiday  |                 |                         | All hours         |
summary: On a 5x8 schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> TRANSITION(DT)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for special days (weekends and holidays), which is a key aspect of categorizing worked time for payroll.

name: 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Regular Day Overtime
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, the first 10 hours on a regular workday (Mon-Thu) are paid at straight time, and all hours after 10 are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon-thu' AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] -> PAY(HOURS_0_TO_10=ST, AFTER(10)=DT)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule defines the straight time and double time thresholds for a specific compressed work week schedule, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Friday Overtime
rule_text:
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Friday        |                 | Up to 10 hours             | After 10 hours     |
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a Friday are paid at time and a half, and all hours after 10 are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon-thu' AND day_of_week == 'FRI' -> PAY(HOURS_0_TO_10=OT, AFTER(10)=DT)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule specifies the overtime pay structure for a scheduled day off (Friday) on a 4x10 schedule, directly relating to the categorization of worked time.

name: 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Regular Day Overtime
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, the first 10 hours on a regular workday (Tue-Fri) are paid at straight time, and all hours after 10 are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue-fri' AND day_of_week IN ['TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> PAY(HOURS_0_TO_10=ST, AFTER(10)=DT)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule defines the straight time and double time thresholds for a specific compressed work week schedule, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Monday Overtime
rule_text:
| Day of Week   | Straight Time   | Time and One Half (1.5x)   | Double Time (2x)   |
|---------------|-----------------|----------------------------|--------------------|
| Monday        |                 | Up to 10 hours             | After 10 hours     |
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a Monday are paid at time and a half, and all hours after 10 are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue-fri' AND day_of_week == 'MON' -> PAY(HOURS_0_TO_10=OT, AFTER(10)=DT)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule specifies the overtime pay structure for a scheduled day off (Monday) on a 4x10 schedule, directly relating to the categorization of worked time.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of service with an Employer, the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits of eight (8) hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a result of the employee's attendance at a funeral or memorial service upon the death of an employee's Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent -inLaw, Grandparent or Sibling. Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: An employee with more than 3 years of service is entitled to up to 3 days of paid bereavement leave (8 hours per day at straight time) to attend a funeral for an immediate family member (Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent-in-Law, Grandparent, or Sibling).
logical_representation: IF years_of_service (llm) > 3 AND bereavement_reason (llm) IN ['SPOUSE', 'CHILD', 'PARENT', 'PARENT_IN_LAW', 'GRANDPARENT', 'SIBLING'] -> PAY(MAX_3_DAYS * 8_HOURS_ST)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule provides for paid time off under specific circumstances, which is a form of compensation for time and falls under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME category.

name: Vacation Pay Tiers (Long-Term Maintenance)
summary: For long-term maintenance employees, vacation pay is a percentage of earnings based on years of service: 6% (0-3 yrs), 7% (3-7 yrs), 8% (7-10 yrs), 9% (10-12 yrs), and 10% (over 12 yrs).
logical_representation: IF maintenance_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM' -> APPLY_PAY(vacation_pay_rate=TIERED_BY_YEARS_OF_SERVICE)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule defines the calculation rate for vacation pay, which is a direct component of an employee's total compensation for their labor, fitting squarely in LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Continuity of Service for Vacation Pay
rule_text: Long term maintenance employees who have a break in service with the Employer will maintain their years of service should the break in service be less than ninety (90) calendar days. A change to the commercial contract whereby an individual is moved from one Signatory Employer to another shall not be considered a break in service. The break in service is not applicable for those who quit or are terminated.
summary: For long-term maintenance employees, years of service (used for calculating vacation pay) are maintained if a break in employment is less than 90 days. Moving between signatory employers is not considered a break in service. This does not apply to employees who quit or are terminated.
logical_representation: IF maintenance_type (llm) == 'LONG_TERM' AND break_in_service_days (llm) < 90 AND employee_status (Unsupported) NOT IN ['QUIT', 'TERMINATED'] -> MAINTAIN(years_of_service (llm))
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule defines how a key metric ('years of service') is maintained or reset, which directly impacts pay entitlements like vacation pay, making it a rule related to labor compensation.

name: CF Industries SDO Schedule Pay
rule_text: Employees will be paid in full for all hours worked each week. (For example, if someone completes the regular 8-9-9-8-8 schedule, they will be compensated for forty-two (42) hours at the regular straight time hourly rate and all required contributions under the collective agreement will be compensated based upon fort-two (42) hours.
summary: At CF Industries, employees on the special 8-9-9-8-8 schedule are paid for 42 straight-time hours for a completed work week.
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'CF_INDUSTRIES' AND schedule_type == '8-9-9-8-8_mon-fri' -> PAY(weekly_hours=42_ST)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule defines the total weekly straight time hours for a unique, site-specific schedule, which is a core component of calculating pay for worked time.

name: CF Industries SDO Pay on Day Off
rule_text: All work on the SDO will be paid in accordance with the number of hours an individual employee has worked since the last SDO. For example: if an individual has worked three (3) of the scheduled nine (9) hour days and are asked to work an SDO, the first five (5) hours on the schedule will be paid at the straight time rate and all additional hours will be compensated at the appropriate overtime rate as per the collective agreement.
summary: At CF Industries, pay for working a Scheduled Day Off (SDO) depends on hours already worked in the pay cycle. The employee is paid straight time until they reach the 42-hour weekly threshold, and any hours beyond that are paid at the applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'CF_INDUSTRIES' AND schedule_type == '8-9-9-8-8_mon-fri' AND is_sdo (llm) == true -> PAY(ST_HOURS = MAX(0, 42 - hours_worked_since_last_sdo (llm)), OT_HOURS = daily_hours - ST_HOURS)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors Association>IBB Local 146>Maintenance Agreement Addendum
reasoning: This rule sets out a specific, conditional calculation for determining the split between straight time and overtime hours, which is a clear function of categorizing worked time for payroll.

name: Maintenance Work Wage Rate
rule_text: Wage rates for maintenance work shall be $0.75 per hour less than base rates set forth in the Area Labour Agreement of the Member Union where such work is to be performed and shall be paid to all employees under the terms of this agreement.
summary: For maintenance work, employees are paid $0.75 per hour less than the base rate specified in the relevant Area Labour Agreement.
logical_representation: IF work_type (llm) == 'MAINTENANCE' -> PAY(base_rate (llm) - 0.75)
reasoning: This rule defines the calculation of a wage rate for a specific type of work, which is a core component of how worked time is compensated.

name: Optional Electronic Pay Records
rule_text: At the Employer's option, electronic pay records and records of Employment may be provided in lieu of  printed  records.
summary: The employer can choose to provide pay records and Records of Employment electronically instead of as printed documents.
logical_representation: EMPLOYER_OPTION(PROVIDE('ELECTRONIC_RECORDS') IN_LIEU_OF PROVIDE('PRINTED_RECORDS'))
reasoning: This rule pertains to the administration and delivery of pay information, which is directly related to the compensation for worked time.

name: Printed Pay Records on Request
rule_text: Upon  request  from  an  employee  that  does  not  have  the  capability  to  access electronic records, printed pay records shall be issued.
summary: If an employee cannot access electronic records and requests them, the employer must provide printed pay records.
logical_representation: IF employee_request (llm) == 'PRINTED_PAY_RECORDS' AND access_capability (llm) == false -> PROVIDE('PRINTED_PAY_RECORDS')
reasoning: This rule establishes an employee's entitlement to a specific format of pay information, making it part of the administration of worked time compensation.

name: Printed Record of Employment on Request
rule_text: Upon request, a printed record of employment will be issued.
summary: An employee can request a printed Record of Employment, and the employer must provide it.
logical_representation: IF employee_request (llm) == 'PRINTED_ROE' -> PROVIDE('PRINTED_ROE')
reasoning: This rule defines an employee's right concerning their employment records, which are linked to their history of worked time and pay.

name: Ft. McMurray Maintenance Wage Rate
rule_text: For projects that are located within a one hundred (100) radius kilometers of Ft. McMurray city hall, wage rates for maintenance shall be 100% of base rates set forth in the Area Labour Agreement.
summary: For maintenance work on projects within a 100 km radius of Ft. McMurray city hall, the wage rate is 100% of the base rate from the Area Labour Agreement, with no reduction.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 100 AND work_type (llm) == 'MAINTENANCE' -> PAY(base_rate (llm) * 1.0)
reasoning: This rule is a location-based exception that sets a specific wage rate, directly impacting the compensation for worked time.

name: Weekly Pay Day
rule_text: Wages will be paid weekly by cheque or other legal tender by the end of the work day on Thursday.
summary: Employees will be paid their weekly wages by the end of the workday every Thursday.
logical_representation: PAYMENT_DUE(WEEKLY, by=EOD_THU)
reasoning: This rule establishes the schedule for paying employees for their worked time, which is a fundamental aspect of labor compensation.

name: Second Shift Pay Day
rule_text: If there is a second shift the weekly cheques will be distributed by the end of the work day Wednesday if available on site.
summary: For employees on a second shift, weekly paycheques will be distributed by the end of the day on Wednesday, provided the cheques are available on site.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == 'SECOND_SHIFT' AND payment_available_on_site (llm) == true -> PAYMENT_DUE(WEEKLY, by=EOD_WED)
reasoning: This rule is an exception to the standard pay schedule based on shift, directly governing the timing of payment for worked hours.

name: Foreperson ICCS Premium
rule_text: General Forepersons and Forepersons who have achieved the status of Industrial Construction Crew Supervisor designation from the Alberta Apprenticeship Industry Training will receive an additional one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) over the regular General Forepersons and Forepersons rates (for all hours worked) contained in the applicable reference agreement. The premium is not to be pyramided.
summary: General Forepersons and Forepersons with an Industrial Construction Crew Supervisor (ICCS) designation receive a non-pyramiding premium of $1.50 per hour on top of their regular rate.
logical_representation: IF is_foreman == true AND certification (llm) == 'ICCS' -> PREMIUM($1.50, non_pyramiding=true)
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific monetary premium paid per hour worked based on an employee's role and certification, directly affecting labor cost and pay.

name: Employer Fund Contributions
rule_text:
Employers will make appropriate contributions to the following funds for those participating trades which  have  the  provision  contained  within  their  respective  Industrial  Construction  Reference Agreement:
- o Building Trades of Alberta
- o Audiometric Testing
- o Construction Employee Family Assistance Program (CEFAP)
- o Case Managed Aftercare (CMAC)
- o Rapid Site Access Program (RSAP)
- o Workforce Development Trust Fund (WFDT)
summary: Employers must contribute to various funds (such as Building Trades of Alberta, CEFAP, etc.) for trades where the relevant Industrial Construction Reference Agreement requires it.
logical_representation: IF reference_agreement_provision (llm) == true for position_classification -> EMPLOYER_CONTRIBUTION(fund_name (llm))
reasoning: This rule defines employer-paid benefits that are calculated based on employee trade and hours worked, forming part of the overall labor compensation package.

name: Enablement Provisions Parity
rule_text: Any enablement provisions made by the Local Unions to the wage rates or benefits  packages and provided to any Employer will be extended to NMA Employers when bidding the same or similar work packages. In these circumstances' maintenance will be at the enabled conditions.
summary: If a Local Union offers special, more favorable wage or benefit conditions ('enablement provisions') to any employer, those same conditions must be extended to NMA Employers bidding on similar work.
logical_representation: IF enablement_provision (llm) == true FOR work_type (llm) -> APPLY_CONDITIONS('enablement_provision')
reasoning: This rule ensures parity in wage and benefit rates under specific circumstances, directly impacting how worked time is compensated.

name: Monetary Change Implementation Timeline
rule_text: Upon renewal of a Local Reference Agreement the Employer will have thirty (30) days from receipt of notification to implement any initial monetary changes.
summary: After a Local Reference Agreement is renewed, the employer has 30 days from being notified to implement any new monetary changes.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'AGREEMENT_RENEWAL' -> IMPLEMENTATION_PERIOD(30_days, from=notification_receipt_date (llm))
reasoning: This rule governs the timing for applying new wage or benefit calculations, which is an administrative aspect of compensating for worked time.

name: Retroactive Pay on Renewal
rule_text: Payment of any initial increase will be paid retroactively to the implementation date.
summary: When a new agreement increases pay, the increase is paid retroactively back to the official implementation date.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'AGREEMENT_RENEWAL' -> PAY(monetary_increase, retroactive_to=implementation_date (llm))
reasoning: This rule dictates how wage increases are calculated and paid out for past worked time, making it a core worked time compensation rule.

name: Alloy Welder Premium on Dispatch
rule_text: Alloy welders with a valid alloy welding certificate will be paid an additional premium of three dollars and twenty-five cents ($3.25) per hour worked if certification was a requirement for dispatch.
summary: If an alloy welding certificate was required for the job, welders with that certificate will receive a premium of $3.25 for each hour worked.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'ALLOY_WELDER' AND certification (llm) == 'ALLOY_WELDING' AND dispatch_requirement (llm) == true -> PREMIUM($3.25)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific monetary premium per hour worked based on skill and job requirements, directly impacting the calculation of pay for worked time.

name: Reclassification to Alloy Welder
rule_text: If a welder on site who was not dispatched as an alloy welder, but has the certification, or is requested to  be  certified  by  the  employer  and  is  requested  to  perform  alloy  welding,  the  worker  will  be  reclassified as an alloy welder and paid the alloy welder premium from the date of re-classification.
summary: A welder not originally dispatched for alloy work will be reclassified as an alloy welder and receive the corresponding pay premium from the date they are asked to perform alloy welding, provided they have or get the required certification.
logical_representation: IF position_classification == 'WELDER' AND certification (llm) == 'ALLOY_WELDING' AND work_performed (llm) == 'ALLOY_WELDING' -> RECLASSIFY('ALLOY_WELDER') AND PAY_PREMIUM(from=reclassification_date (llm))
reasoning: This rule governs how an employee's classification and pay rate change based on the type of work performed, which is a key aspect of worked time compensation.

name: Alloy Welder Premium Non-Pyramiding
rule_text: This premium shall not pyramid on an overtime hour; however, it will attract applicable Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
summary: The alloy welder premium is a flat hourly addition and is not multiplied by overtime rates.
logical_representation: IF premium_type (llm) == 'ALLOY_WELDER' -> CONSTRAINT(non_pyramiding_on_overtime)
reasoning: This rule specifies how a premium is calculated in relation to overtime, directly impacting the total compensation for worked time.

name: Alloy Welder Premium on Vacation and Holiday Pay
rule_text: This premium shall not pyramid on an overtime hour; however, it will attract applicable Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
summary: The alloy welder premium is included in the calculation for an employee's Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
logical_representation: IF premium_type (llm) == 'ALLOY_WELDER' -> INCLUDE_IN_CALCULATION('VACATION_PAY', 'STAT_HOLIDAY_PAY')
reasoning: This rule defines how a premium affects other pay calculations (Vacation/Stat Holiday pay), which is a key part of total compensation for worked time.

name: Final Pay on Termination
rule_text: Employees who are laid off or terminated from the services of the Company shall normally receive their final wages, vacation pay due, and unemployment insurance record of earnings before they leave the jobsite.
summary: Normally, when an employee is laid off or terminated, they must receive their final pay, vacation pay, and Record of Employment (ROE) before leaving the jobsite.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] -> PROVIDE(final_pay_and_roe, before_leaving_jobsite)
reasoning: This rule governs the process and timing for issuing final payment for all worked time upon termination, making it an administrative rule for labor compensation.

name: Final Pay by Mail Exception
rule_text: It is recognized that there will be certain occasions when the above procedure is not possible. In these cases final wages, vacation pay due, and Records of Earnings (ROE's) will be mailed to the employee's last recorded  home  address  within  three  (3)  working  days  exclusive  of  Saturdays,  Sundays  and Statutory  Holidays.
summary: If it's not possible to provide final pay on-site at termination, the company must mail the final pay and Record of Employment (ROE) to the employee's last known address within three business days.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] AND on_site_payment_not_possible (llm) == true -> MAIL(final_pay_and_roe, within=3_business_days)
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative procedure and timeline for issuing final payment for worked time, classifying it under labor compensation administration.

name: ROE Filing and Mailing
rule_text: EI  Records  of  Earnings  (ROE's)  will  be  filed  electronically  or  at  the  employees' written request be mailed Express Post to the employees' last recorded home address within three (3) working days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays.
summary: Records of Employment (ROEs) will be filed electronically. However, if an employee makes a written request, the ROE will be sent by Express Post to their last known address within three business days.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] AND employee_request (llm) == 'MAILED_ROE' -> MAIL(roe_express_post, within=3_business_days) ELSE FILE(roe_electronically, within=3_business_days)
reasoning: This rule specifies the method and deadline for providing employment records tied to an employee's worked time and earnings, falling under the administration of labor compensation.

name: Final Pay with Electronic Deposit
rule_text: When electronic deposits are made, the final deposit and other termination document mailings/filings must be made by the next pay period.
summary: If final pay is made by electronic deposit, the payment and all associated termination documents must be processed by the next regular pay period.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) IN ['LAID_OFF', 'TERMINATED'] AND payment_method (llm) == 'ELECTRONIC_DEPOSIT' -> SUBMIT(final_pay_and_documents, by=next_pay_period)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific deadline for final payment and documentation when using electronic deposit, which is an administrative rule for compensating worked time.

name: Penalty for Late Mailed Final Pay
rule_text: Should wages and vacation pay earnings not be mailed within this time period noted above, the  Company  will  pay  a  penalty  of  $100.00  per  day,  exclusive  of  Saturdays,  Sundays  and Statutory Holidays, until the mailing or filing is made.
summary: If the company fails to mail final pay within the required three business days, it must pay a penalty of $100 for each business day until it is sent.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_mail_delay (llm) > 3_business_days -> PENALTY($100_per_day)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for failing to adhere to the payment schedule for worked time, directly relating to labor compensation enforcement.

name: Penalty for Late Electronic Final Pay
rule_text: Should wages and vacation pay not be electronically submitted by the next pay period the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 per day, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays. The penalty will be imposed from the pay date for which the electronic deposit was not received.
summary: If the company fails to electronically deposit final pay by the next pay period, it must pay a penalty of $100 for each business day of delay, starting from the missed pay date.
logical_representation: IF payment_method (llm) == 'ELECTRONIC_DEPOSIT' AND final_pay_electronic_deposit_is_late (llm) == true -> PENALTY($100_per_day, from=missed_pay_date)
reasoning: This rule establishes a financial penalty for late payment of final wages, which is an enforcement mechanism for worked time compensation.

name: Correction Period for Final Pay Error
rule_text: In the event that there is a payroll error (miscalculation) on the final electronic deposit, the Company will have three (3) days, after notification is provided to the Company in accordance with the Company's normal payroll query process, to provide a make-up payment.
summary: If there is a miscalculation on a final electronic pay deposit, the company has three days after being notified to make a corrective payment.
logical_representation: IF payroll_error_type (llm) == 'FINAL_PAY_MISCALCULATION' -> GRACE_PERIOD(3_days_for_correction, after=notification)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific timeframe for correcting pay errors, which is a procedural aspect of ensuring accurate compensation for worked time.

name: Penalty for Uncorrected Final Pay Error
rule_text: Should this make-up payment not be made within the three (3) days, the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 from the pay date of the final electronic deposit.
summary: If the company fails to correct a final pay error within the three-day grace period, it must pay a $100 penalty.
logical_representation: IF payroll_error_type (llm) == 'FINAL_PAY_MISCALCULATION' AND correction_delay > 3_days -> PENALTY($100)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty for failing to correct errors in worked time compensation within a specified period.

name: Grievance Deadline for Final Pay Issues
rule_text: Complaints/grievances with respect to non-receipt of final wages, vacation pay due and employment insurance record of earnings must be raised to the Company in a timely fashion, in any event, not more than ten (10) days, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Holidays, from date of lay-off/termination.
summary: An employee must file any complaint or grievance about not receiving final pay or their ROE within ten business days of their layoff or termination date.
logical_representation: IF grievance_type (llm) == 'NON_RECEIPT_FINAL_PAY' -> SUBMISSION_DEADLINE(10_business_days, from=termination_date)
reasoning: This rule sets a procedural time limit for disputes regarding final compensation for worked time, classifying it under the administration of labor pay.

name: Correction for Major Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should employees be short paid ten (10) or more hours or equivalent value on their weekly pay cheque or electronic deposit, the Company will provide an adjustment on a subsequent pay date but not later than ten (10) days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays after notification of the shortage is received in writing and acknowledged by the Company.
summary: If an employee is short-paid by 10 or more hours, the company must correct the error and pay the difference within ten business days of being notified in writing.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) >= 10 -> CORRECTION_DUE(within=10_business_days, from=notification)
reasoning: This rule defines the process and timeline for correcting significant errors in payment for worked time, which is central to labor compensation.

name: Penalty for Uncorrected Major Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should this payment not be made within the allotted ten (10) days, the Company will pay the penalty amount noted in article 9.400 above from the date the issue was raised by the employee and received in writing and acknowledged by the Company.
summary: If the company fails to correct a major pay shortage (10+ hours) within ten business days, it must pay a $100 per day penalty starting from the date the error was reported.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) >= 10 AND correction_delay > 10_business_days -> PENALTY($100_per_day, from=notification_date)
reasoning: This rule creates a financial penalty for failing to correct significant pay errors related to worked time, serving as an enforcement mechanism.

name: Correction for Minor Pay Shortage
rule_text: In the event that there is a payroll error (miscalculation) on the weekly pay cheque or electronic deposit where an employee is short paid less than ten (10) hours or equivalent, the Company will have two (2) payroll periods, after notification is provided to the Company in accordance with the Company's normal payroll query process, to provide a make-up payment.
summary: If an employee is short-paid by less than 10 hours, the company has two pay periods after being notified to correct the error and make the payment.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) < 10 -> CORRECTION_DUE(within=2_pay_periods, from=notification)
reasoning: This rule specifies the timeline for correcting minor errors in payment for worked time, which is part of the administration of labor compensation.

name: Penalty for Uncorrected Minor Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should this make-up payment not be made within the two (2) payroll periods, the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 per day from the date the Company was notified.
summary: If the company fails to correct a minor pay shortage (less than 10 hours) within two pay periods, it must pay a $100 per day penalty starting from the date the error was reported.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours (llm) < 10 AND correction_delay > 2_pay_periods -> PENALTY($100_per_day, from=notification_date)
reasoning: This rule establishes a financial penalty for the failure to correct minor payment errors for worked time, acting as an enforcement mechanism.

name: Penalty for Late Payroll Query
rule_text: Should  the  employee  not  submit  a  payroll  query  within  three  (3)  weeks  of  the  payroll  error (miscalculation) the penalty payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day will be applicable on day 15 from the submission of the query.
summary: If an employee waits more than three weeks to report a minor pay error, the company still gets a grace period (approx. two pay periods or 14 days) to fix it after notification. The $100/day penalty for non-payment will only begin on the 15th day after the late query was submitted.
logical_representation: IF query_submission_delay_weeks (llm) > 3 AND correction_is_late (llm) == true -> PENALTY_START(day=15, from=query_submission_date)
reasoning: This rule modifies the start date of a penalty for late payment of worked time based on when the employee reports the error, making it an administrative detail of compensation enforcement.

name: Overpayment Recovery Process
rule_text: When the Company or the Employee becomes aware of an overpayment, the Company the Union and the Employee will meet to negotiate the repayment terms.
summary: If a payroll overpayment occurs, the company, the union, and the employee must meet to negotiate the terms of how the overpayment will be repaid.
logical_representation: IF payroll_error_type (llm) == 'OVERPAYMENT' -> NEGOTIATE(repayment_terms, parties=['COMPANY', 'UNION', 'EMPLOYEE'])
reasoning: This rule defines the procedure for handling pay errors, specifically overpayments, which is a key administrative function related to worked time compensation.

name: List of Recognized Statutory Holidays
rule_text:
11.100 The following days will constitute the recognized holidays within the terms of this Agreement.

| 1. New Years Day   | 6. Civic Holiday                           | 11. Christmas Day                          |
|--------------------|--------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------|
| 2. Family Day      | 7. Labour Day                              | 12. Boxing Day                             |
| 3. Good Friday     | 8. National Day for Truth & Reconciliation | 8. National Day for Truth & Reconciliation |
| 4. Victoria Day    | 9. Thanksgiving Day                        | 9. Thanksgiving Day                        |
| 5. Canada Day      | 10. Remembrance Day                        | 10. Remembrance Day                        |
summary: This rule lists the 12 officially recognized statutory holidays covered by the agreement: New Year's Day, Family Day, Good Friday, Victoria Day, Canada Day, Civic Holiday, Labour Day, National Day for Truth & Reconciliation, Thanksgiving Day, Remembrance Day, Christmas Day, and Boxing Day.
logical_representation: DEFINE is_stat_holiday = ['New Years Day', 'Family Day', 'Good Friday', 'Victoria Day', 'Canada Day', 'Civic Holiday', 'Labour Day', 'National Day for Truth & Reconciliation', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Remembrance Day', 'Christmas Day', 'Boxing Day']
reasoning: This rule defines which specific days are classified as statutory holidays, a fundamental component for determining special pay rates and time off, which falls under the category of how labor time is categorized and compensated.

name: Automatic Recognition of New Government Holidays
rule_text: Any other  holiday  proclaimed  by  either  the  Provincial  or  Federal  Government  will  be  automatically recognized within this Agreement.
summary: If the Provincial or Federal Government proclaims a new public holiday, it will be automatically added to the list of recognized statutory holidays under this agreement.
logical_representation: IF government_proclaimed_holiday (llm) == true -> ADD_TO_LIST(is_stat_holiday)
reasoning: This rule expands the definition of what constitutes a statutory holiday, directly impacting pay and scheduling. This is a core aspect of labor time management.

name: Default Holiday Observance on Calendar Day
rule_text: Each of the recognized holidays listed in Article 12.100 shall be observed on the calendar day on which it occurs.
summary: By default, all statutory holidays are to be observed on their actual calendar date.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true -> OBSERVE_ON(calendar_date)
reasoning: This rule establishes the default timing for holiday observance, which is essential for scheduling and determining which day receives special pay treatment. It is part of categorizing worked time.

name: Moving Specific Holidays into the Work Week
rule_text: When any of these three identified holidays: Family Day, Victoria Day, Labour Day fall outside of the regularly scheduled work week, they will be moved into the work week for observance.
summary: If Family Day, Victoria Day, or Labour Day falls on a weekend or a non-scheduled workday, the day of observance will be moved to a regularly scheduled workday.
logical_representation: IF holiday_name (llm) IN ['Family Day', 'Victoria Day', 'Labour Day'] AND falls_outside_work_week (llm) == true -> MOVE_OBSERVANCE_TO(work_week)
reasoning: This rule modifies the schedule for specific holidays, directly affecting which day is treated as the holiday for pay and time-off purposes. This is a rule about how time is scheduled and categorized.

name: Holiday Pay or Day Off at Company Discretion
rule_text: On the day of observance, the Company may either pay the workforce at double-time (2) the total package straight time hourly rate or provide the day off.
summary: On a statutory holiday, the company has the option to either pay employees double their straight-time hourly rate for working or give them the day off.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == true -> CHOOSE(PAY(2.0), PROVIDE(day_off))
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the pay rate (double time) or entitlement (day off) for a statutory holiday, which is a core function of categorizing and compensating labor time.

name: Holiday Harmonization for Maintenance Projects
rule_text: On maintenance, the overriding factor is harmonizing statutory holidays with in-plant workers. Should the Owner determine another day be recognized for its people, this day will be recognized by Company forces.
summary: For maintenance projects, if the facility owner designates a different day for a statutory holiday for their own workers, the company's employees will also observe the holiday on that same day.
logical_representation: IF project_type (llm) == 'MAINTENANCE' -> SET_HOLIDAY_OBSERVANCE(client_designated_holiday_date (llm))
reasoning: This rule provides an override for holiday scheduling based on project type and client requirements, directly impacting which day is paid as a holiday. This is a key aspect of managing and categorizing worked time.

name: Conditions for Holiday Harmonization
rule_text:
The day of observance for the Holiday remains as identified, unless direction has been given  by  the  Client  requesting  for  our  employers  to  observe  it  at  the  same  time  as  the  in-plant personnel.
In  order for the harmonization principle to be applicable, the Contractor must notify the GPMC in advance of the pending movement of the Holiday along with the designated day for observance. The designated day to for observance must be applicable to all contractors and all trades across the entire facility.
summary: For holiday harmonization to occur, three conditions must be met: 1) The client must officially request the change, 2) The contractor must notify the GPMC in advance, and 3) The new observance day must apply to all contractors and trades at the site.
logical_representation: REQUIREMENT FOR(HARMONIZATION): client_request_for_observance (llm) == true AND contractor_notification_to_gpmc (llm) == true AND designated_day_applies_facility_wide (llm) == true
reasoning: This rule sets the specific conditions under which a holiday's observance date can be changed. This is a procedural rule that directly governs the application of holiday pay and scheduling, making it part of labor time management.

name: Employer Holiday Posting Obligation
rule_text: Employers will post the date to be observed no later than seven (7) days prior to the holiday.
summary: The employer is required to post a notice of the date a statutory holiday will be observed at least seven days in advance.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: POST(holiday_observance_date) >= 7_days_prior_to_holiday
reasoning: This rule is a procedural requirement related to scheduling and notifying employees about which day will be treated as a holiday. It's an administrative part of managing labor time and pay.

name: Default Observance on Harmonization Failure
rule_text: In the absence of meeting the above and providing proper notification, the holiday will be observed in accordance with the provisions outlined in Article 12.000.
summary: If the conditions for harmonizing a holiday with the client's schedule are not met, the holiday will be observed according to the standard rules of the agreement.
logical_representation: IF harmonization_conditions_met (llm) == false -> APPLY_RULES('DEFAULT_STAT_HOLIDAY')
reasoning: This rule acts as a fallback, determining which set of holiday rules (and therefore pay/scheduling) applies when harmonization fails. It is a key part of the logic for categorizing and paying for labor time.

name: Reporting Pay Minimum
rule_text: When an employee reports for work, unless previously advised there is no work available, they shall be entitled to two (2) hours pay at the appropriate day or shift rate.
summary: An employee who reports for their shift, without being told in advance not to, is guaranteed a minimum of two hours of pay at their applicable rate.
logical_representation: IF prior_notification_of_no_work (llm) == false -> MIN(2_HOURS_PAY)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment guarantee (show-up time) for employees who report to work, which is a fundamental aspect of defining payable time.

name: Payment for Time Worked or Waited on Site
rule_text: Should the employee start work or be required to wait at the jobsite, they shall be paid for hours worked or actual waiting time past the two (2) hours minimum.
summary: If an employee who reports to work either starts their job or is required to wait, they will be paid for all the time they worked or waited. The total hours paid will be the greater of the actual time on site (working or waiting) or the two-hour minimum.
logical_representation: IF work_commenced (Unsupported) == true OR is_required_to_wait (llm) == true -> PAY(MAX(2, daily_hours))
reasoning: This rule defines how payable hours are calculated when an employee starts work or waits on site, ensuring their compensation is at least the two-hour reporting minimum. It directly governs the calculation of paid time.

name: Daily Travel, Company Transportation Provided (45-120km)
rule_text: On those projects that are located between forty-five (45) radius kilometers to one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from Edmonton and/or Calgary City Hall(s) or other Hiring Hall locations, the Company shall supply suitable transportation to and from the project and mutually agreed to pick-up points.
summary: The company must provide transportation for projects located between 45 and 120 radius kilometers from a city hall or hiring hall.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) >= 45 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 120 -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This rule outlines a non-monetary travel benefit (transportation) based on project distance, which is a core component of subsistence and travel allowances.

name: Daily Travel, Vehicle Allowance (45-120km)
rule_text: Alternatively,  the  Company  shall  pay  to  each  employee  a  vehicle  allowance  at  the  rate established  by  the  Canadian  Revenue  Agency  per  road  kilometer  for  each  day  worked  or reported  for  work,  from  the  edge  of  the  forty-five  (45)  radius  kilometer  free  zone  to  the project and return.
summary: As an alternative to providing transportation on projects 45-120km from a hiring hall, the company can pay a vehicle allowance at the CRA rate for the distance travelled beyond the 45km free zone, round trip.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) >= 45 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 120 AND transportation_provided (llm) == false -> ALLOWANCE(CRA_RATE_PER_KM, for_distance > 45, round_trip)
reasoning: This rule provides a monetary allowance for travel, which is a form of subsistence or remote work compensation.

name: Subsistence Amount Updates
rule_text: Subsistence amounts to be cross referenced with any changes made through the CLRA and these amounts will be updated within the Agreement in a timely manner.
summary: Subsistence payment amounts defined in this agreement will be updated if changes are made through the CLRA.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(Subsistence amounts must align with CLRA updates)
reasoning: This rule governs the value of the subsistence allowance, making it directly related to that topic. It's a constraint or an update mechanism for the allowance.

name: Subsistence or Camp Eligibility (>120km)
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid or camp provided on projects which are more than one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary or other Hiring Hall locations.
summary: For projects over 120 radius kilometers from a hiring hall, the company must either pay a subsistence allowance or provide camp accommodation.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 120 -> PROVIDE(SUBSISTENCE_OR_CAMP)
reasoning: This is the primary eligibility rule for subsistence or camp accommodation based on project distance.

name: Standard Daily Subsistence Rate
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid at a rate of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) per day worked or reported for.
summary: The standard daily subsistence allowance is $150.00 per day worked or reported for, unless a location-specific rate applies.
logical_representation: ALLOWANCE(150.00, per_day_worked_or_reported)
reasoning: This rule defines the base monetary value of the subsistence allowance.

name: Location-Specific Daily Subsistence Rates
rule_text: In the following areas, subsistence will be paid at a rate per day worked or reported for as noted: [table of locations and rates]
summary: In specific locations like Fort McMurray ($200), Grande Prairie ($205), and others listed, a different daily subsistence rate applies instead of the standard $150.
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) IN ['Athabasca', 'Bonnyville', 'Camrose', 'Caroline', 'Canmore/Exshaw', 'Cold Lake', 'Drumheller', 'Edson', 'Elk Point/Vermillion', 'Forestburg', 'Fox Creek', 'Fort McMurray', 'Grande Cache', 'Grande Prairie', 'Hanna', 'Hardisty/Wainwright', 'High Level', 'Hinton', 'Lethbridge', 'Lloydminster', 'Medicine Hat', 'Peace River', 'Pincher Creek/Waterton', 'Red Deer', 'Rock Mountain House', 'Stettler', 'Swan Hills', 'Vallyview', 'Whitecourt', 'Wasbasca Area'] -> ALLOWANCE(SPECIFIC_RATE_PER_LOCATION, per_day_worked_or_reported)
reasoning: This rule provides specific monetary amounts for the subsistence allowance based on geographic location.

name: 7-Day Subsistence for Remote Sites (>475km)
rule_text: On sites which are four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers plus as noted above, subsistence will be paid on a seven (7) day per week basis.
summary: For projects located 475 radius kilometers or more from a hiring hall, subsistence is paid for all seven days of the week, not just days worked.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) >= 475 -> PAY(SUBSISTENCE, 7_days_per_week)
reasoning: This rule defines the payment frequency and continuity of the subsistence allowance under specific distance conditions.

name: Subsistence Forfeiture due to Absenteeism
rule_text: Forfeiture of subsistence allowance due to absenteeism may be waived if the reason for absence is acceptable to the Employer.
summary: An employee may lose their subsistence allowance for being absent, but this can be waived if the employer accepts the reason for the absence.
logical_representation: IF is_absent (llm) == true AND is_absence_preauthorized (Unsupported) == false -> FORFEIT(SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition under which the entitlement to a subsistence allowance can be lost.

name: Additional Subsistence Day for Travel (>200km)
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees not residing in the area where the project is located will be eligible to receive one additional day of subsistence for either the day before commencing work or the day after completing the work assignment, where the project is greater than two hundred (200) road kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary, or other Hiring Hall  locations. This  payment  will  be  made  for  the  preceding  or  succeeding  day  where substantiated by verifiable proof that accommodation was used (i.e. receipt or registration verification).
summary: Non-local employees on projects more than 200 road kilometers away can receive one extra day of subsistence for travel, either before starting or after finishing, if they provide proof of accommodation.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident (Unsupported) == false AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 200 AND claim_type (Unsupported) == 'PROOF_OF_ACCOMMODATION' -> PAY(1_DAY_SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule provides an additional monetary allowance related to remote work travel, which is a core part of subsistence rules.

name: Initial and Terminal Travel Allowance (120-300km, eff 2025)
rule_text: As of May 4, 2025, Initial and terminal travel which will be paid as follows from the above: | 120-200 Radius Kilometers 200-300 Radius Kilometers | $ 116.00 each way, $ 166.00 each way, |
summary: Effective May 4, 2025, employees receive an initial and terminal travel allowance of $116 each way for projects 120-200km away, and $166 each way for projects 200-300km away.
logical_representation: IF validity_start_date >= '2025-05-04' AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) >= 120 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 200 -> ALLOWANCE(116.00, each_way); IF validity_start_date >= '2025-05-04' AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 200 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) <= 300 -> ALLOWANCE(166.00, each_way)
reasoning: This defines a specific travel allowance based on distance and effective date, which is a key component of subsistence and remote work compensation.

name: Forfeiture of Travel Allowance if Client Provides Transportation
rule_text: No travel shall be payable under this Article if the Client provides transportation to the work site and return.
summary: If the client provides transportation to and from the worksite, no travel allowance will be paid to the employee.
logical_representation: IF client_provides_transportation (llm) == true -> FORFEIT(TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition under which the entitlement to a travel allowance is nullified.

name: Initial and Terminal Travel for Remote Sites (>475km, eff 2025)
rule_text: As of May 4, 2025, on jobs beyond the four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers initial  and  terminal  travel  amounts  will  be  mutually  agreed  between  the  Union  and  the Employer to a maximum of $455.00 each way or airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: Effective May 4, 2025, for jobs over 475 km away, initial and terminal travel pay is mutually agreed upon, up to a maximum of $455 each way, or the cost of airfare with proof.
logical_representation: IF validity_start_date >= '2025-05-04' AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km (Unsupported) > 475 -> ALLOWANCE(MUTUALLY_AGREED, MAX(455.00_each_way)) OR PAY(AIRFARE, with_proof)
reasoning: This rule outlines a special travel allowance for very remote projects, a key aspect of subsistence compensation.

name: Review of Initial and Terminal Travel Amounts
rule_text: Initial  and  terminal  travel  amounts  will  be  reviewed  by  the  National  Maintenance  Council should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.
summary: The amounts for initial and terminal travel will be reviewed by the National Maintenance Council if there are changes in the reference agreements.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(Initial and terminal travel amounts must be reviewed based on reference agreement changes)
reasoning: This rule governs the value of the travel allowance, making it directly related to the subsistence topic.

name: Payout Timing for Initial Travel
rule_text: Initial  travel  amounts  will  be  paid  after  fifteen  (15)  calendar  days  on  the  job  or  at  lay-off.
summary: The initial travel allowance is paid to the employee after they have worked for 15 calendar days on the job, or when they are laid off.
logical_representation: IF days_on_job (llm) >= 15 OR employee_status (Unsupported) == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(INITIAL_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule specifies the conditions and timing for the payment of a travel allowance, which is part of the overall subsistence package.

name: Payout Timing for Terminal Travel
rule_text: Terminal travel will be paid at lay-off.
summary: The terminal travel allowance is paid to the employee at the time of lay-off.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(TERMINAL_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule specifies the timing for the payment of a travel allowance, which is part of the subsistence package.

name: Forfeiture of Travel Payments (Quit/Termination)
rule_text: Employees who quit or are terminated for cause prior to the entitlement payment of either initial or terminal amounts are not entitled to any travel payments outstanding.
summary: If an employee quits or is fired for cause before receiving their initial or terminal travel pay, they forfeit that payment.
logical_representation: IF employee_status (Unsupported) == 'QUIT' OR employee_status (Unsupported) == 'TERMINATED_FOR_CAUSE' -> FORFEIT(TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule defines conditions under which an employee loses their entitlement to the travel allowance, a key aspect of subsistence rules.

name: Ineligibility of Local Residents for Subsistence and Travel
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for  Accommodation  Allowance  and  initial/terminal  travel
summary: On a project that qualifies for subsistence, employees who are local residents of that area are not eligible to receive the accommodation allowance (subsistence) or initial/terminal travel pay.
logical_representation: IF is_subsistence_project (llm) == true AND is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true -> FORFEIT(ACCOMMODATION_ALLOWANCE) AND FORFEIT(INITIAL_TERMINAL_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule establishes a major eligibility condition (local residency) for receiving subsistence and travel allowances.

name: Daily Travel for Local Residents on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: but  will  receive  daily  travel  payments pursuant to Article 14.100 (a) if they reside outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone around the project.
summary: Although local residents on a subsistence project don't get the accommodation allowance, they can still receive daily travel payments if they live more than 45 radius kilometers from the project site.
logical_representation: IF is_subsistence_project (llm) == true AND is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true AND distance_from_residence_to_project (llm) > 45 -> PAY(DAILY_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific travel allowance for a subset of employees (local residents) under certain conditions, making it a subsistence-related rule.

name: Transportation for Non-Domiciled Employees on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees domiciled outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job will be provided transportation to and from the job or paid a vehicle allowance at the rate established by the Canadian Revenue Agency.
summary: On a subsistence project, employees living more than 45km from the job site must be provided with transportation or be paid a vehicle allowance at the CRA rate.
logical_representation: IF is_subsistence_project (llm) == true AND distance_from_domicile_to_project (llm) > 45 -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION) OR ALLOWANCE(CRA_RATE_PER_KM)
reasoning: This rule describes a daily travel benefit (transportation or allowance) for employees on a subsistence project, directly relating to the topic.

name: Forfeiture of Daily Travel for Subsistence Choice
rule_text: Employees who are offered camp accommodation and choose to receive subsistence instead are not entitled to daily travel outside of the forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job.
summary: If an employee is offered camp accommodation but opts to take the subsistence allowance instead, they are not eligible for daily travel payments for commuting from outside the 45km zone.
logical_representation: IF camp_offered (llm) == true AND employee_choice (llm) == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> FORFEIT(DAILY_TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition of choice that leads to the forfeiture of a daily travel allowance, a key aspect of subsistence rules.

name: Mandatory Transportation for Fort McMurray
rule_text: Ft.  McMurray residents or those employees accommodated in Ft. McMurray will be provided with transportation to and from the jobsite by the Employer.
summary: For jobs near Fort McMurray, the employer must provide transportation for any employees who are residents of or are staying in Fort McMurray.
logical_representation: IF project_location (Unsupported) == 'Fort McMurray' AND (is_local_resident (Unsupported) == true OR is_accommodated_in_location (llm) == true) -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This is a location-specific rule regarding the provision of travel benefits, which falls under the subsistence and travel topic.

name: Travel Entitlements to Fort McMurray from Edmonton
rule_text: Employees travelling to Ft. McMurray from Edmonton will be paid initial and terminal travel pursuant to Article 14.100 b) and provided with camp accommodation or accommodation allowance.
summary: Employees who travel from Edmonton to work in Fort McMurray are entitled to initial and terminal travel pay, as well as either camp accommodation or a subsistence allowance.
logical_representation: IF travel_origin (llm) == 'Edmonton' AND project_location (Unsupported) == 'Fort McMurray' -> PAY(INITIAL_TERMINAL_TRAVEL) AND PROVIDE(CAMP_OR_ACCOMMODATION_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule combines multiple subsistence-related entitlements (travel pay, accommodation) for a specific travel route and destination.

name: Standard Work Day, 5x8 Schedule
rule_text: Eight (8) hours per day shall constitute a day's work and forty (40) hours per week, Monday to Friday inclusive, shall constitute a week's work.
summary: A standard workday is 8 hours, and a standard workweek is 40 hours, from Monday to Friday.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' -> SET(daily_hours_ST=8, weekly_hours_ST=40, work_days=['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'])
reasoning: This rule defines the standard hours of work for a specific schedule, which is fundamental to categorizing worked time.

name: Standard Work Day Timings, 5x8 Schedule
rule_text: The regular starting time shall be eight (8) o'clock a.m., and the regular quitting time shall be four-thirty (4:30) o'clock p.m. Start times may be staggered two (2) hours between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. as job conditions warrant.
summary: The standard workday is 8:00 AM to 4:30 PM, but start times can be staggered between 7:00 AM and 9:00 AM if needed for the job.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' -> SET(shift_start_time='08:00', shift_end_time='16:30', start_time_flexibility=['07:00'-'09:00'])
reasoning: This rule specifies the timing of the workday, which directly relates to how hours are counted and categorized.

name: Optional Work Week, 4x10 Schedule
rule_text: As an option, ten (10) hours per day, Monday to Thursday or Tuesday to Friday may be worked at straight time.
summary: An optional 4-day, 10-hour work week (Monday-Thursday or Tuesday-Friday) can be implemented where all 10 hours are paid at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon-thu' OR schedule_type == '4x10_tue-fri' -> SET(daily_hours_ST=10)
reasoning: This rule defines an alternative work schedule and its straight time hours, a core component of categorizing worked time.

name: 4x10 Schedule Establishment
rule_text: The ten (10) hour system must operate for a minimum period of four (4) consecutive days before it is established as the regular hours of work. Once established it becomes the regular hours of work for those so assigned.
summary: A 4-day, 10-hour schedule must be followed for at least four consecutive days to be officially considered the regular work schedule for the assigned employees.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' AND shift_consecutive_days >= 4 -> SET(schedule_is_established=true)
reasoning: This rule sets the condition for when a work schedule becomes official, which impacts how pay and overtime are calculated.

name: 4x10 Schedule Union Notification
rule_text: When establishing a four (4) day ten (10) hour work week, the Employer will advise the affected Local Union office that a four (4) day ten (10) hour option is in place and declare if it is a Monday to Thursday, or Tuesday to Friday work pattern.
summary: When a 4-day, 10-hour work week is established, the employer must notify the local union office and specify whether it's a Monday-Thursday or Tuesday-Friday schedule.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'ESTABLISH_4x10' -> ACTION(NOTIFY_UNION(schedule_type))
reasoning: This is a procedural rule tied to the establishment of work schedules, which is classified under worked time.

name: Short Term Work on 4x10 Projects
rule_text: Where a multi trade project is scheduled under the four (4) ten (10) hour shift system and an Employer secures short term work that may not provide for forty (40) hours of work, all hours worked shall be paid for in keeping with the provisions applicable to the four (4) ten (10) hour shift.
summary: On a multi-trade project using a 4-day, 10-hour schedule, if an employee works on a short-term job with less than 40 hours available, all hours worked are still paid according to the 4x10 overtime rules.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' AND project_type == 'MULTI_TRADE' AND weekly_hours < 40 -> APPLY_PAY_RULES('4x10')
reasoning: This rule dictates how to apply pay rules under specific conditions (short-term work on a 4x10 schedule), directly affecting the calculation of worked time.

name: Paid Breaks on 10-Hour Shifts
rule_text: When ten (10) hour shifts are worked, in lieu of the work breaks and lunch breaks provided herein, the Employer shall have the option of scheduling two breaks of one half (½) hour each, paid at the applicable rate, approximately equally spaced in the ten (10) hour shift.
summary: On 10-hour shifts, the employer can provide two paid 30-minute breaks, roughly evenly spaced, instead of the usual breaks.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours == 10 -> PROVIDE(2 x 30_minute_paid_breaks)
reasoning: This rule defines paid break entitlements, which are a component of the total hours paid and thus fall under worked time.

name: Missed Break Penalty, Straight Time Day
rule_text: On a straight time, day, the employee will be compensated an additional thirty (30) minutes paid at the time and one-half rate.
summary: If an employee misses their break on a regular straight-time day, they must be paid an extra 30 minutes at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF work_day_type == 'STRAIGHT_TIME' AND event (Unsupported) == 'MISSED_BREAK' -> PAY(0.5_hours * 1.5)
reasoning: This rule specifies a penalty payment calculated based on the employee's pay rate, which is a direct aspect of worked time calculation.

name: Missed Break Penalty, Overtime Day
rule_text: On an overtime day, the employee will be compensated an additional thirty (30) minutes at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: If an employee misses their break on an overtime day, they must be paid an extra 30 minutes at the relevant overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF work_day_type == 'OVERTIME' AND event (Unsupported) == 'MISSED_BREAK' -> PAY(0.5_hours * applicable_overtime_rate)
reasoning: This rule defines a penalty payment calculated based on overtime rates, making it a rule about how worked time is compensated.

name: Staggering Paid Breaks
rule_text: Under schedules utilizing a half (½) hour (paid break) system, they may be staggered one (1) hour either way to accommodate production schedules and emergencies. The above penalty clauses outlined in 15.100(i) a) and b) will apply in instances when the staggered one half (½) hour (paid break) is moved greater than one (1) hour either way to accommodate production schedules and emergencies.
summary: Paid 30-minute breaks can be moved up to one hour earlier or later. If the break is moved by more than one hour, it is considered a missed break and the associated penalties apply.
logical_representation: IF break_schedule_deviation_hours > 1 -> APPLY_PENALTY('MISSED_BREAK')
reasoning: This rule sets conditions on break timing that can trigger penalty pay, which is part of calculating total compensation for worked time.

name: Day Shift Definition
rule_text: Employees working a day shift defined as a shift starting at 8:00 a.m. shall work eight (8) hours for eight (8) hours pay.
summary: A day shift is defined as starting at 8:00 AM, where employees work 8 hours and are paid for 8 hours.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == 'DAY' AND shift_start_time (llm) == '08:00' -> PAY(8_hours_ST) FOR WORK(8_hours)
reasoning: This rule defines what constitutes a standard day shift and its pay, a fundamental aspect of categorizing worked time.

name: Shift Premium for Non-Daywork
rule_text: Employees working any shift that is outside of daywork conditions, shall receive a shift premium of four dollars and fifty cents ($4.50) per hour worked.
summary: Employees who work shifts that are not considered standard day shifts will receive an extra $4.50 per hour.
logical_representation: IF shift_type != 'DAY' -> PREMIUM($4.50)
reasoning: This rule specifies a premium payment based on the type of shift worked, which is a key part of calculating pay for worked time.

name: Unpaid Lunch Break
rule_text: The mid-shift lunch break will be of one half (1/2) hour in duration and will be unpaid.
summary: The standard mid-shift lunch break is 30 minutes long and is unpaid.
logical_representation: SET(lunch_break_duration=0.5_hours, lunch_break_pay_status='UNPAID')
reasoning: This rule defines the status of a lunch break (unpaid), which affects the total paid hours for a shift.

name: Shift Change Notice Penalty
rule_text: Where employees are requested to take a shift change, as much notice as possible will be given. If eight (8) hours notice is not provided then all regular hours worked on the first shift on the new schedule will be paid at time and one-half the straight time total package rate (1-1/2).
summary: If an employee's shift is changed with less than 8 hours' notice, all regular hours on their first new shift must be paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF shift_change_notice_hours < 8 -> PREMIUM(1.5) ON first_shift_regular_hours
reasoning: This rule imposes a penalty payment (overtime rate) for insufficient notice, directly impacting the calculation of worked time.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule, Daily OT
rule_text: Monday ... Friday | 8 hours | Up to 2 hours | After 10 hours
summary: On a 5-day, 8-hour schedule from Monday to Friday, the first 8 hours are straight time, the next 2 hours are time and a half, and any hours worked beyond 10 are double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN ['MON','TUE','WED','THU','FRI'] -> (IF daily_hours <= 8 -> PAY(ST)) AND (IF daily_hours > 8 AND daily_hours <= 10 -> PAY(OT)) AND (IF daily_hours > 10 -> PAY(DT))
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the thresholds for straight time, overtime, and double time on weekdays for a standard 5x8 schedule.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule, Weekend & Holiday
rule_text:
Saturday | | | All hours
Sunday | | | All hours
Stat Holiday | | | All hours
summary: On a 5-day, 8-hour schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PAY(DT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for non-standard workdays (weekends, holidays), which is a core function of categorizing worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Weekdays
rule_text:
Monday to Thursday:
Monday ... Thursday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours
Friday | | Up to 10 hours | After 10 hours
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour (Mon-Thu) schedule: work on Mon-Thu is straight time for the first 10 hours and double time after. Work on Friday is time and a half for the first 10 hours and double time after.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon-thu' -> (IF day_of_week IN ['MON','TUE','WED','THU'] AND daily_hours > 10 -> PAY(DT)) AND (IF day_of_week == 'FRI' AND daily_hours <= 10 -> PAY(OT)) AND (IF day_of_week == 'FRI' AND daily_hours > 10 -> PAY(DT))
reasoning: This rule defines the specific overtime thresholds and rates for a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, directly related to categorizing worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Weekend & Holiday
rule_text:
Saturday | | | All hours
Sunday | | | All hours
Stat Holiday | | | All hours
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour (Mon-Thu) schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon-thu' AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PAY(DT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for non-standard workdays (weekends, holidays) for a 4x10 schedule, which is a core function of categorizing worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Weekdays
rule_text:
Tuesday to Friday:
Monday | | Up to 10 hours | After 10 hours
Tuesday ... Friday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour (Tue-Fri) schedule: work on Tue-Fri is straight time for the first 10 hours and double time after. Work on Monday is time and a half for the first 10 hours and double time after.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue-fri' -> (IF day_of_week IN ['TUE','WED','THU','FRI'] AND daily_hours > 10 -> PAY(DT)) AND (IF day_of_week == 'MON' AND daily_hours <= 10 -> PAY(OT)) AND (IF day_of_week == 'MON' AND daily_hours > 10 -> PAY(DT))
reasoning: This rule defines the specific overtime thresholds and rates for a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, directly related to categorizing worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Weekend & Holiday
rule_text:
Saturday | | | All hours
Sunday | | | All hours
Stat Holiday | | | All hours
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour (Tue-Fri) schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue-fri' AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) -> PAY(DT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for non-standard workdays (weekends, holidays) for a 4x10 schedule, which is a core function of categorizing worked time.

name: First Overtime Meal Break
rule_text: When an employee works beyond ten (10) hours per day they shall be entitled to a meal break and a meal supplied by the Company.
summary: An employee is entitled to a meal and a meal break, provided by the company, when they work more than 10 hours in a day.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 -> PROVIDE(meal_and_break)
reasoning: This rule establishes the primary trigger (working beyond 10 hours) for a meal entitlement, which is the core definition of a meal allowance rule.

name: Subsequent Overtime Meal Breaks
rule_text: The meal break will be provided after ten (10) hours of work and subsequent meal breaks each four (4) hours thereafter.
summary: After the first meal break at 10 hours, an employee is entitled to another meal break every four hours they continue to work.
logical_representation: IF daily_overtime_hours > 2 -> PROVIDE(meal_and_break) AND PROVIDE(meal_and_break) EVERY 4_hours_thereafter
reasoning: This rule defines the recurring entitlement for meal breaks during extended overtime, making it a meal allowance rule.

name: Overtime Meal Break Extension, 4x10 Schedule
rule_text: When the four (4) ten (10) hour day option is worked, recognizing emergency situations will arise, if the Company has not scheduled in excess of the ten (10) hour shift, the Company shall be granted a one (1) hour extension where a meal and meal break are not required.
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour schedule, if overtime was not pre-scheduled, the company can have an employee work up to 11 hours before a meal and break are required.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' AND overtime_type == 'UNSCHEDULED' -> SET(meal_break_trigger_hours=11)
reasoning: This rule modifies the trigger for a meal entitlement based on the work schedule and overtime type, classifying it under meal allowances.

name: Scheduled Overtime Meal Break Trigger
rule_text: When an employee works Scheduled Overtime (work performed on Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays they shall be entitled to a meal break when overtime work exceeds ten (10) hours.
summary: For scheduled overtime on Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, an employee gets a meal break after working more than 10 hours.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'SCHEDULED' AND (day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_stat_holiday == true) AND daily_hours > 10 -> PROVIDE(meal_break)
reasoning: This rule specifies the conditions (day of week, hours worked) for a meal break entitlement during scheduled overtime, clearly making it a meal allowance rule.

name: Call-Out Overtime Meal Break Trigger
rule_text: When an employee works Short Notice Emergency Call-Out Overtime (overtime work performed other than continuous with the regular work day or Scheduled Overtime) they shall be entitled to a meal break when overtime work exceeds four (4) hours.
summary: For emergency call-out overtime, an employee is entitled to a meal break after working more than 4 hours.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'CALL_OUT' AND daily_hours > 4 -> PROVIDE(meal_break)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific trigger (4 hours on call-out) for a meal entitlement, placing it in the meal allowance category.

name: Overtime Meal Break Pay and Duration
rule_text: All overtime meal breaks will be thirty (30) minutes in duration and will be paid for at straight time rates.
summary: Overtime meal breaks are 30 minutes long and are paid at the employee's straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF meal_break_type == 'OVERTIME' -> SET(duration=0.5_hours, pay_rate='ST')
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay and duration for a meal break entitlement, making it a meal allowance rule. It also touches on worked time by specifying the pay rate.

name: Overtime Meal Break Calculation Exclusion
rule_text: However, in calculating entitlement to a meal, the thirty (30) minute break shall not count as overtime work.
summary: The paid 30-minute overtime meal break does not count as hours worked when determining eligibility for subsequent meal breaks.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: meal_break_duration EXCLUDED FROM hours_worked FOR subsequent_meal_entitlement_calculation
reasoning: This rule clarifies how meal break time is treated for calculation purposes, which is an integral part of administering meal allowance rules.

name: Foreman Extra Hours Meal Exclusion
rule_text: When a foreperson is required to: 1) Start up to one (1) hour earlier, or 2) Finish up to one (1) hour later, or 3) Start up to one-half (1/2) hour earlier and finish up to one-half (1/2) hour later than the foreperson's crews, for the purposes of organizing work, obtaining permits or facilitating a transition to another shift, the foreperson shall not be entitled to a meal or meal break as per Clause 16.600 unless those provisions are applicable to the rest of the crew.
summary: A foreman who works up to an hour before or after their crew for prep work is not entitled to an overtime meal unless the rest of the crew also qualifies for one.
logical_representation: IF is_foreman == true AND extra_prep_hours <= 1 AND crew_meal_entitlement == false -> FORFEIT(meal_break)
reasoning: This rule creates an exclusion for meal entitlements based on an employee's role (foreman) and work pattern, making it a meal allowance rule.

name: Scheduled Overtime Meal Allowance in Lieu
rule_text: A) Scheduled Overtime: (Notification must be provided prior to the end of the current shift for the following day(s), to be considered as scheduled overtime). 1) a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight time total package hourly rate in lieu of the meal break: and 2) a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If a meal cannot be provided during scheduled overtime, the employee receives 30 minutes of pay at straight time plus a 15-minute paid rest break at the applicable rate.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'SCHEDULED' AND meal_provision_status == 'NOT_PROVIDED' -> PAY(0.5_hours_ST) AND PROVIDE(15_minute_paid_break)
reasoning: This rule defines the monetary and time-based compensation provided when a meal entitlement cannot be fulfilled, which is a core component of meal allowance policies.

name: Unscheduled Overtime Meal Allowance in Lieu
rule_text: B) Unscheduled Overtime: 1) a payment of forty dollars ($40.00) as a meal allowance. 2) a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight time total package hourly rate in lieu of the meal break: and 3) a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay
summary: If a meal cannot be provided during unscheduled overtime, the employee receives a $40 meal allowance, 30 minutes of pay at straight time, and a 15-minute paid rest break at the applicable rate.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'UNSCHEDULED' AND meal_provision_status == 'NOT_PROVIDED' -> ALLOWANCE($40.00) AND PAY(0.5_hours_ST) AND PROVIDE(15_minute_paid_break)
reasoning: This rule specifies the combination of a flat-rate allowance and paid time as compensation for a missed meal, making it a meal allowance rule.

name: Subsistence and Meal Allowance Exclusion
rule_text: There shall be no meal allowance applicable to those receiving subsistence, however any reduction to the current subsistence rates will attract a meal allowance payment equivalent to the reduction.
summary: Employees receiving subsistence payments are not eligible for overtime meal allowances, unless their subsistence rate is reduced, in which case they will be compensated for the amount of the reduction.
logical_representation: IF is_receiving_subsistence == true -> FORFEIT(meal_allowance)
reasoning: This rule establishes an exclusion for meal allowances based on the receipt of subsistence, directly linking the two and thus falling under meal allowances.

name: Camp Meal and Meal Allowance
rule_text: Where a camp is provided, employees will not receive the forty dollars ($40.00) meal allowance where they are able to receive a camp meal at the end of their shift.
summary: If a work camp is provided and an employee can get a meal there after their shift, they will not receive the $40 meal allowance.
logical_representation: IF camp_provided == true AND camp_meal_available == true -> FORFEIT(ALLOWANCE($40.00))
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition (availability of a camp meal) that negates a monetary meal allowance, making it a meal allowance rule.

name: Call-Out Minimum Pay
rule_text: Employees called out between regular shifts will be entitled to a minimum of two (2) hours pay at double (2x) the straight time total package hourly rate.
summary: If an employee is called out to work between their regular shifts, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours' pay at double time.
logical_representation: IF event (Unsupported) == 'CALL_OUT' -> MIN(2_hours_DT)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum pay guarantee for a specific type of work event (call-out), which is a core concept of worked time calculation.

name: Call-Out Pay Rate
